entry.title: Monday, September 4 Evening Update
entry.summary: Today firefighters checked for hot spots, rehabilitated dozer lines, and monitored the fire. Mop-up along the fires perimeter is completed and resources found minimal heat. Fire behavior was minimal with smoldering of heavy fuels (i.e. logs and stumps) in the interior and occasional creeping in the interior islands of unburned fuels. Most of the fire resources will be demobilized tonight and will head either to a new fire assignment or are up for required days off in the morning. Three engines, one crew, and local heavy equipment will remain on the fire in the coming days to wrap-up the remaining rehabilitation and monitor the fire. Tomorrow the fire will be transferred back to the local fire jurisdictions.

Monday, September 4, 2017 Morning Update

Happy Labor Day

SARTIN DRAW FIRE UPDATE

MT DNRC COUNTY ASSIST TEAM

David Hamilton, Incident Commander

SIZE: 99,735 acres

CONTAINMENT: 85%
CAUSE: Natural
FIRE LOCATION: 20 miles NE of Ashland, MT

RESOURCES:
20 Engines
5 Crews (20 people/crew, 4 - Type 2 Crews & 1 - Type 1 Crew)

11 Heavy Equipment (5 dozers, 3 skidgines, 4 water tender)

1 Helicopter

227 Total Personnel


Weather: A Red Flag Warning will be in effect until 9 PM tonight. Winds will shift back towards the north this morning and will again be 10-20 mph during the afternoon, with gusts up to 25 mph. A Canadian cold front passed through the area early this morning, producing much cooler temperatures, higher humidities, and gusty north winds. Cool temperatures will continue through Tuesday, followed by a warming trend on Wednesday and Thursday.

Fire Situation: Fire resources will mop-up and secure 200 feet in along the fires perimeter to increase containment. Perform rehab on all interior dozer lines and where appropriate, rehab perimeter dozer lines. Pockets of unburned fuel (i.e. vegetation) in the deep interior of the fire may burn and produce smoke. There will be two 20 person crews, two engines, one water tender, and one skidgine working on the Snider Branch portion of the fire. They will be securing the perimeter and mopping up.

Yesterday, firefighters along with local ranchers accomplished mopping up hot spots 3 chains (200 feet) in on most areas of the fire. Their hard work increased the containment on the Sartin Draw and Snider Fires to 85%. Firelines held throughout the day with the windy hot conditions. The increase in fire size is due to the Sartin Draw and Snider fires being combined.

On Saturday, September 2, the County Assist Team also assumed management of the Snider Fire (6,393 acres) burning in Rosebud County. Thursday morning the two fires burned together along a small section of the Tongue River Road. The Snider fire was lightning caused and first reported on August 31. The fire is located 16 miles east of Colstrip. Rosebud Fire Warden, local ranchers and heavy equipment worked hard and did a good job slowing the progress of the fire.


FIRE INFORMATION PHONE: 406-200-8516

INCIWEB: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5573/

FACEBOOK: @sartindrawfire

EMAIL: sartindraw@gmail.com


Stage I Fire Restrictions are in Effect in Eastern Montana.

CAMPFIRES and other fires are prohibited except in approved recreation sites, as designated on the fire prevention order. Liquid petroleum and LPG stoves that can be turned on and off are allowed.

SMOKING is prohibited outside of vehicles, buildings, and developed recreation sites, unless you are in a 3-foot-diameter area cleared of all burnable vegetation.

For more information about fire restrictions, go to: http://firerestrictions.us

Sunday, September 3, Evening Update

Incident: Sartin Draw Fire Wildfire
Released: 14 min. ago

Related Information

  • Sunday, September 3 Evening Update (jpeg 484 kb)

Weather: A Red Flag Warning will be in effect until 9 PM Monday. A Canadian cold front will pass through the area early Monday morning, producing much cooler temperatures, higher humidities and gusty north/northeast winds. Cool temperatures will persist through Tuesday, followed by a warming trend on Wednesday and Thursday.

Fire Situation: Firefighters along with local ranchers accomplished mopping up hot spots 3 chains (200 feet) in on most areas of the fire. Their hard work increased the containment on the Sartin Draw and Snider Fires to 85%. Firelines held throughout the day with the windy hot conditions. The southwest portion of the fire has a few old stumps burning that crews were extinguishing through the day. There were some interior smokes from hot spots on the southeast portion of the fire. The northeast portion of the fire had very little heat today, after the burning operations yesterday. Fire resources mopped-up around cottonwoods on the northwest portion of the fire near the Tongue River. A Type 1 Hot Shot crew and County engines worked on the Snider Fire, they constructed solid line on the south/southeast and north portions of the fire.

On Saturday, September 2 at 12:00 PM, the County Assist Team also assumed management of the Snider Fire (6,393 acres) burning in Rosebud County. Thursday morning the two fires burned together along a small section of the Tongue River Road. The Snider fire was lightning caused and first reported at 12:00 PM on August 31. The fire is located 16 miles east of Colstrip. Rosebud Fire Warden, local ranchers and heavy equipment worked hard and did a good job slowing the progress of the fire.

Planned Actions for Tomorrow: Fire resources will continue to mop-up and secure 200 feet in along the fires perimeter to increase containment. Rehab on all interior dozer lines will start tomorrow, along with some appropriate perimeter dozer line rehab. Pockets of unburned fuel (i.e. vegetation) in the deep interior of the fire may burn and produce smoke.

Closures: There are no closures currently. Expect heavy fire vehicle traffic along the Tongue River Road and other surrounding roads near the fire.

Evacuations: Pre-evacuation notice is in place for residents located N of Merchant Cut, W of Hwy 59 and S of 674 Road. Contact the Fire Information phone line listed below for Red Cross Shelter needs.

Sunday, September 3, 2017 Morning Update


Weather: A Red Flag Warning is effect from 9 AM today to 9 PM Monday. Weather today will be hot and very dry. High temperatures will approach 100 degrees in spots and humidities will fall to around 10% in the afternoon. Northwest winds will increase by late morning, with expected gusts to 30 mph when the cold front passes through.

Sartin Draw Fire: Today fire resources will improve line, mop-up containment lines, and patrol portions of the fire. The main priority is to keep the fire in place through the winds today. Yesterday, firefighters in conjunction with local ranchers put in another hard day of work and made great progress in containing and suppressing the fire. There are containment lines (dozer constructed, black line and/or road systems) along the edge of the fire.

Snider Fire: On Saturday, September 2 at 12:00 PM, the County Assist Team also assumed management of the Snider Fire burning in Rosebud County. On Friday, September 1st the two fires burned together along a small section of the Tongue River Road. Aviation resources flew the fires yesterday and determined the fire is 6,393 acres in size. The Snider fire was reported around 12:00 PM on Thursday, August 31 and the cause is natural. The fire is 16 miles east of Colstrip, MT and started on private land. Rosebud fire warden, local ranchers and some heavy equipment worked hard for days to slow the progress of the fire. Currently a Type 1 Hot Shot crew is working the Snider Fire. The priority today is to secure the SE and S sides of the fire, continue to build and improve line, burn out areas of unburned line as conditions and resources allow and mop-up 200 feet in from the fire perimeter.

22 Engines
5 Crews (4 Type 2 Initial Attack 20 person crews and 1 Type 1 Hot Shot 20 person crew)

Saturday, September 2, 2017 Evening Update

Firefighters in conjunction with local ranchers put in another hard day of work and are making great progress in putting this fire to bed. In preparation for the forecasted weather fire resources conducted two large burn operations today to reduce the amount of unburned vegetation inside the fire perimeter. This reduces the likelihood that unburned vegetation in the fire area will ignite and cast embers over the fireline when high winds arrive. The fire has containment lines (dozer constructed, black line and/or road systems) along the edge of the fire and is not spreading.

At 12:00 PM today the County Assist Team also assumed management of the Snider Fire burning in Rosebud County. Thursday morning the two fires burned together along a small section of the Tongue River Road. Aviation resources flew the fires today and determined the fire is 6,393 acres in size. More information on this fire will be available tomorrow in our morning update.

Tomorrows planned actions include: patrol the western side of the fire along the Tongue River Road and Beaver Creek Road; improve line and mop-up containment lines on the southern edge of the fire; and hold and improve line and mop-up 3 chain (200 feet) in on the eastern side of the fire. Fire resources on the northern side will hold and improve line along Foster Creek Road and burn out pockets of unburned vegetation that are well in the interior of the containment line.

Friday, September 1, 2017 Evening Update
SIZE: 80,000 acres CONTAINMENT: 10% CAUSE: Unknown

The northeast portion had some spot fires start outside the fireline due to gusty winds. Engines and heavy equipment are working to construct line around those spot fires. Along the northern edge of the fire, dozer line was put in and crews conducted a burn operation to reinforce the fires perimeter. The western side of the fire is not burning and is in patrol status. Landowners in partnership with Local, State and Federal fire resources have been working non-stop to prohibit the progression of the Sartin Draw Fire and having great success. Along the Tongue River Road, it is visible to see where the Snider Fire burned up to the road on the west and on the east side of the road you can see where the Sartin Fire burned, essentially bringing the two fires together.

SARTIN DRAW FIRE UPDATE
David Hamilton, Incident Commander

Friday, September 1, 2017 Morning Update

Fire Situation: Local, State and Federal fire resources have been working diligently to slow and stop the progression of the Sartin Draw fire since it was initially reported. The fire has been progressing to the northeast. Fire resources are working to keep the fire east of the Tongue River, south of the 621 and 664 roads, west of Highway 59 and north of Beaver Creek, Beaver Stacy Roads and Merchant Cut Across. Dozerline is being reinforced with firing operations to increase depth to secure fireline. Engines, skidgines and hand crews are extinguishing heat along the fire perimeter and assisting with firing operations.

There are no closures currently. Expect heavy fire vehicle traffic along the Tongue River Road and other surrounding roads near the fire.

The Montana Department of Natural Resources and Conservation’s County Assist Team assumed management of the fire on August 31, 2017 at 4:30 pm. They were able to bring additional fire resources with them to assist existing firefighters on the fireline.

Severe drought with hot and windy conditions has given zero relief for firefighters. In addition to the Sartin Draw Fire firefighters have been chasing and suppressing numerous fires in the area for the last seven days from a series of lightning storms that rolled through the area. This is on top of the extremely busy fire season this summer in Eastern Montana, due to severe drought conditions.

Evacuations: Pre-evacuation notice is in place for residents N of Merchant Cut, W of Hwy 59 and S of 674 Road.

Fire Statistics:
Size: 80,000 acres
Containment: 0%
Cause: Unknown
Location: 20 miles NE of Ashland, MT
Resources: 27 Engines 3 Crew 7 Heavy Equipment
